messages-56036d53-6017-4a33-9161-21f3649: [{"role": "system", "content": "You are a helpful and intelligent assistant that can only respond by using the tools provided to you. For every user request, choose the most relevant tool available to generate your response. If no tool is suitable for answering the question, kindly reply with something like 'I'm sorry, I can't help with that right now.' or 'That's outside what I can assist with.' Always keep your tone polite, concise, and friendly."}, {"role": "user", "content": "hi"}, {"role": "assistant", "content": "I'm ASI1-Mini, your intelligent and helpful assistant from Fetch.ai Inc. I'm pleased to meet you! How can I assist you today?\n"}, {"role": "user", "content": "Are there any active weather alerts in Texas?"}, {"role": "assistant", "content": "", "tool_calls": [{"id": "call_0Xidi", "index": 0, "type": "function", "function": {"name": "get_alerts", "arguments": "{\"state\":\"TX\"}"}}]}, {"role": "tool", "tool_call_id": "call_0Xidi", "content": "type='text' text=\" Event: Severe Thunderstorm Warning Area: Smith, TX; Upshur, TX; Wood, TX Severity: Severe Description: At 740 PM CDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line\\nextending from 6 miles west of Rosewood to near Hawkins to near\\nLindale, moving east at 30 mph.\\n\\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.\\n\\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\\n\\nIMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to\\nroofs, siding, and trees.\\n\\nLocations impacted include...\\nRed Springs, Rosewood, Hawkins, Lindale, Hoard, Big Sandy, Gilmer,\\nWinona, Bettie, Midway, Grice, Hainesville, and Pritchett. Instructions: For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a\\nbuilding.\\n---\\n Event: Severe Thunderstorm Watch Area: Collin, TX; Cooke, TX; Dallas, TX; Delta, TX; Denton, TX; Ellis, TX; Fannin, TX; Grayson, TX; Henderson, TX; Hill, TX; Hopkins, TX; Hunt, TX; Johnson, TX; Kaufman, TX; Lamar, TX; Navarro, TX; Rains, TX; Rockwall, TX; Tarrant, TX; Van Zandt, TX Severity: Severe Description: SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WATCH 278 REMAINS VALID UNTIL 10 PM CDT THIS\\nEVENING FOR THE FOLLOWING AREAS\\n\\nIN TEXAS THIS WATCH INCLUDES 20 COUNTIES\\n\\nIN CENTRAL TEXAS\\n\\nHENDERSON             HILL\\n\\nIN NORTH CENTRAL TEXAS\\n\\nCOLLIN                COOKE                 DALLAS\\nDELTA                 DENTON                ELLIS\\nFANNIN                GRAYSON               HOPKINS\\nHUNT                  JOHNSON               KAUFMAN\\nLAMAR                 NAVARRO               RAINS\\nROCKWALL              TARRANT               VAN ZANDT\\n\\nTHIS INCLUDES THE CITIES OF ALLEN, ARLINGTON, ATHENS, BONHAM,\\nBURLESON, CANTON, CARROLLTON, CLEBURNE, COMMERCE, COOPER,\\nCORSICANA, DALLAS, DENISON, DENTON, EAST TAWAKONI, EDGEWOOD,\\nEMORY, ENNIS, FLOWER MOUND, FORNEY, FORT WORTH, FRISCO,\\nGAINESVILLE, GRAND SALINE, GREENVILLE, GUN BARREL CITY, HEATH,\\nHILLSBORO, KAUFMAN, LEWISVILLE, MCKINNEY, MIDLOTHIAN, PARIS,\\nPLANO, POINT, ROCKWALL, SHERMAN, SULPHUR SPRINGS, TERRELL, VAN,\\nWAXAHACHIE, AND WILLS POINT. Instructions: None\\n---\\n Event: Special Weather Statement Area: Henderson Severity: Moderate Description: At 723 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near\\nAthens, moving east at 30 mph.\\n\\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and half inch hail.\\n\\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\\n\\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\\nunsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is\\npossible.\\n\\nThis strong thunderstorm will be near...\\nLake Palestine around 745 PM CDT.\\n\\nOther locations impacted by this storm include Murchison, New York,\\nLaRue, Moore Station, Poynor, and Coffee City. Instructions: If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.\\n\\nTorrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm and may lead to\\nlocalized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded\\nroadways.\\n\\nFrequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.\\nLightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe\\nshelter inside a building or vehicle.\\n\\nA Severe Thunderstorm Watch remains in effect until 1000 PM CDT for\\ncentral and north central Texas.\\n---\\n Event: Special Weather Statement Area: Wood; Upshur; Smith Severity: Moderate Description: At 716 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along\\na line extending from Hainesville to near Edom. Movement was east at\\n30 mph.\\n\\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and pea size hail.\\n\\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\\n\\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\\nunsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is\\npossible.\\n\\nLocations impacted include...\\nRed Springs, Carroll, Rosewood, Hawkins, Lindale, Hoard, Winona, Big\\nSandy, Mineola, Grice, and Hainesville. Instructions: If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.\\n\\nThese storms may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio\\nstations and available television stations for additional information\\nand possible warnings from the National Weather Service.\\n---\\n Event: Flash Flood Warning Area: Henderson, TX Severity: Severe Description: FFWFWD\\n\\nThe National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a\\n\\n* Flash Flood Warning for...\\nSoutheastern Henderson County in central Texas...\\n\\n* Until 930 PM CDT.\\n\\n* At 715 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing\\nheavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 3 inches of rain\\nhave fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are\\nforecast. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.\\n\\nHAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.\\n\\nSOURCE...Radar.\\n\\nIMPACT...Flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas,\\nhighways, streets, and underpasses as well as other\\npoor drainage and low lying areas.\\n\\n* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...\\nAthens, Malakoff, Trinidad, Caney City, Coon Creek Lake, Forest\\nGrove Reservoir, Trinidad Lake, Cedar Creek Reservoir, Cross\\nRoads, Log Cabin, Star Harbor, Poynor, Crescent Heights, LaRue,\\nNew York and Mankin. Instructions: Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\\n---\\n Event: Special Weather Statement Area: Lipscomb; Roberts; Hemphill Severity: Moderate Description: At 709 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 10\\nmiles northwest of Lora, or 12 miles north of Miami, moving northeast\\nat 40 mph.\\n\\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and half inch hail.\\n\\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\\n\\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\\nunsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is\\npossible.\\n\\nLocations impacted include...\\nCanadian. Instructions: If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.\\n---\\n Event: Severe Thunderstorm Watch Area: Brown, TX; Kimble, TX; McCulloch, TX; Mason, TX; Menard, TX; San Saba, TX; Sutton, TX Severity: Severe Description: THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE HAS ISSUED SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WATCH\\n280 IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 PM CDT THIS EVENING FOR THE FOLLOWING\\nAREAS\\n\\nIN TEXAS THIS WATCH INCLUDES 7 COUNTIES\\n\\nIN WEST CENTRAL TEXAS\\n\\nBROWN                 KIMBLE                MASON\\nMCCULLOCH             MENARD                SAN SABA\\nSUTTON\\n\\nTHIS INCLUDES THE CITIES OF BRADY, BROWNWOOD, CHAPPEL, CHEROKEE,\\nCLEO, ERNA, FIFE, FORT MCKAVETT, FREDONIA, HARKEYVILLE, HEXT,\\nINDIAN CREEK, JUNCTION, KATEMCY, KOOCKVILLE, LOHN, LONDON,\\nLOYAL VALLEY, MASON, MENARD, PONTOTOC, ROCHELLE, ROOSEVELT,\\nSAN SABA, SEGOVIA, SONORA, STREETER, TELEGRAPH, AND VOCA. Instructions: None\\n---\\n Event: Severe Thunderstorm Watch Area: Bandera, TX; Burnet, TX; Edwards, TX; Gillespie, TX; Kerr, TX; Kinney, TX; Llano, TX; Maverick, TX; Real, TX; Uvalde, TX; Val Verde, TX Severity: Severe Description: THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE HAS ISSUED SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WATCH\\n280 IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 PM CDT THIS EVENING FOR THE FOLLOWING\\nAREAS\\n\\nIN TEXAS THIS WATCH INCLUDES 11 COUNTIES\\n\\nIN SOUTH CENTRAL TEXAS\\n\\nBANDERA               BURNET                EDWARDS\\nGILLESPIE             KERR                  KINNEY\\nLLANO                 MAVERICK              REAL\\nUVALDE                VAL VERDE\\n\\nTHIS INCLUDES THE CITIES OF BANDERA, BRACKETTVILLE, BURNET,\\nDEL RIO, EAGLE PASS, FREDERICKSBURG, KERRVILLE, LEAKEY, LLANO,\\nROCKSPRINGS, AND UVALDE. Instructions: None\\n---\\n Event: High Wind Watch Area: Guadalupe Mountains of Eddy County; Guadalupe Mountains Above 7000 Feet; Guadalupe and Delaware Mountains Severity: Severe Description: The High Wind Watch has been replaced. Please see the latest information from NWS Midland/Odessa TX on this developing situation. Instructions: Monitor the latest forecasts and warnings for updates.\\n\\nUse caution if flying low near the mountains as severe turbulence is\\npossible.\\n---\\n Event: High Wind Warning Area: Guadalupe Mountains of Eddy County; Guadalupe Mountains Above 7000 Feet; Guadalupe and Delaware Mountains Severity: Severe Description: * WHAT...For the High Wind Warning, southwest winds 35 to 45 mph\\nwith gusts up to 65 mph expected. For the High Wind Watch, west\\nwinds 35 to 45 mph with gusts up to 65 mph possible.\\n\\n* WHERE...Guadalupe Mountains of west Texas and Southeast New Mexico.\\n\\n* WHEN...For the High Wind Warning, from 11 AM MDT /noon CDT/ to 9\\nPM MDT /10 PM CDT/ Sunday. For the High Wind Watch, from Monday\\nmorning through Monday evening.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...Travel will be difficult, especially for high profile\\nvehicles like campers, vans, and tractor trailers. Aviation\\ninterests may experience localized but extreme turbulence, or\\nstrong downward airflows if flying in the near the Guadalupe\\nMountains. Instructions: Monitor the latest forecasts and warnings for updates.\\n\\nUse caution if flying low near the mountains as severe turbulence is\\npossible.\\n---\\n Event: High Wind Watch Area: Guadalupe Mountains of Eddy County; Guadalupe Mountains Above 7000 Feet; Guadalupe and Delaware Mountains Severity: Severe Description: * WHAT...For the High Wind Warning, southwest winds 35 to 45 mph\\nwith gusts up to 65 mph expected. For the High Wind Watch, west\\nwinds 35 to 45 mph with gusts up to 65 mph possible.\\n\\n* WHERE...Guadalupe Mountains of west Texas and Southeast New Mexico.\\n\\n* WHEN...For the High Wind Warning, from 11 AM MDT /noon CDT/ to 9\\nPM MDT /10 PM CDT/ Sunday. For the High Wind Watch, from Monday\\nmorning through Monday evening.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...Travel will be difficult, especially for high profile\\nvehicles like campers, vans, and tractor trailers. Aviation\\ninterests may experience localized but extreme turbulence, or\\nstrong downward airflows if flying in the near the Guadalupe\\nMountains. Instructions: Monitor the latest forecasts and warnings for updates.\\n\\nUse caution if flying low near the mountains as severe turbulence is\\npossible.\\n---\\n Event: Red Flag Warning Area: Sacramento Foothills and Guadalupe Mountains; Chaves County Plains; Eddy Plains; Lea; Loving; Guadalupe Mountains Above 7000 Feet; Guadalupe and Delaware Mountains; Van Horn and Highway 54 Corridor; Eastern Culberson County; Reeves County Plains; Marfa Plateau; Davis Mountains; Davis Mountains Foothills Severity: Severe Description: ...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM NOON CDT /11 AM MDT/ TO 10 PM\\nCDT /9 PM MDT/ SUNDAY FOR 20 FOOT WINDS OF 20 MPH OR GREATER,\\nRELATIVE HUMIDITY OF 15 PERCENT OR LESS, AND VERY HIGH FIRE DANGER\\nACROSS SOUTHEAST NEW MEXICO AND PORTIONS OF WEST TEXAS...\\n\\n...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH\\nMONDAY EVENING FOR 20 FOOT WINDS OF 20 MPH OR GREATER, RELATIVE\\nHUMIDITY OF 15 PERCENT OR LESS, AND VERY HIGH FIRE DANGER ACROSS\\nSOUTHEAST NEW MEXICO AND PORTIONS OF WEST TEXAS...\\n\\n...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH\\nMONDAY EVENING FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY ACROSS SOUTHEAST\\nNEW MEXICO AND PORTIONS OF WEST TEXAS...\\n\\nThe National Weather Service in Midland/Odessa has issued a Red\\nFlag Warning for wind and low relative humidity, which is in\\neffect from noon CDT /11 AM MDT/ to 10 PM CDT /9 PM MDT/ Sunday.\\nA Fire Weather Watch has also been issued. This Fire Weather\\nWatch for wind and low relative humidity is in effect from Monday\\nafternoon through Monday evening. The Fire Weather Watch is no\\nlonger in effect.\\n\\n* WINDS...West 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph. Higher winds\\nand gusts in the mountains.\\n\\n* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 5 percent.\\n\\n* RFTI...6 to 8 or critical to extreme.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.\\nOutdoor burning is not recommended.\\n\\n* SEVERITY...\\n\\nFUELS (ERC)...70th-89th percentile...4 (out of 5).\\n\\nWEATHER...Near Critical...2 (out of 5).\\n\\nFIRE ENVIRONMENT...6 (out of 10). Instructions: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions\\nare either occurring now or will shortly. A combination of strong\\nwinds, low relative humidity and warm temperatures will increase\\npotential for fire growth.\\n\\nA Fire Weather Watch means that critical fire weather conditions\\nare forecast to occur. Listen for later forecasts and possible\\nRed Flag Warnings.\\n---\\n Event: Red Flag Warning Area: Chinati Mountains Severity: Severe Description: ...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM NOON CDT /11 AM MDT/ TO 10 PM\\nCDT /9 PM MDT/ SUNDAY FOR 20 FOOT WINDS OF 20 MPH OR GREATER,\\nRELATIVE HUMIDITY OF 15 PERCENT OR LESS, AND VERY HIGH FIRE DANGER\\nACROSS SOUTHEAST NEW MEXICO AND PORTIONS OF WEST TEXAS...\\n\\n...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH\\nMONDAY EVENING FOR 20 FOOT WINDS OF 20 MPH OR GREATER, RELATIVE\\nHUMIDITY OF 15 PERCENT OR LESS, AND VERY HIGH FIRE DANGER ACROSS\\nSOUTHEAST NEW MEXICO AND PORTIONS OF WEST TEXAS...\\n\\n...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH\\nMONDAY EVENING FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR THE CHINATI\\nMOUNTAINS...\\n\\nThe National Weather Service in Midland/Odessa has issued a Red\\nFlag Warning for wind and low relative humidity, which is in\\neffect from noon to 10 PM CDT Sunday. A Fire Weather Watch has\\nalso been issued. This Fire Weather Watch for wind and low\\nrelative humidity is in effect from Monday afternoon through\\nMonday evening.\\n\\n* WINDS...West 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 35 mph.\\n\\n* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 6 percent.\\n\\n* RFTI...8 or extreme.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...\\n\\n* SEVERITY...\\n\\nFUELS (ERC)...70th-89th percentile...4 (out of 5).\\n\\nWEATHER...Near Critical...2 (out of 5).\\n\\nFIRE ENVIRONMENT...6 (out of 10). Instructions: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions\\nare either occurring now or will shortly. A combination of strong\\nwinds, low relative humidity and warm temperatures will increase\\npotential for fire growth.\\n\\nA Fire Weather Watch means that critical fire weather conditions\\nare forecast to occur. Listen for later forecasts and possible\\nRed Flag Warnings.\\n---\\n Event: Fire Weather Watch Area: Sacramento Foothills and Guadalupe Mountains; Chaves County Plains; Eddy Plains; Lea; Loving; Guadalupe Mountains Above 7000 Feet; Guadalupe and Delaware Mountains; Van Horn and Highway 54 Corridor; Eastern Culberson County; Reeves County Plains; Marfa Plateau; Davis Mountains; Davis Mountains Foothills Severity: Severe Description: ...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM NOON CDT /11 AM MDT/ TO 10 PM\\nCDT /9 PM MDT/ SUNDAY FOR 20 FOOT WINDS OF 20 MPH OR GREATER,\\nRELATIVE HUMIDITY OF 15 PERCENT OR LESS, AND VERY HIGH FIRE DANGER\\nACROSS SOUTHEAST NEW MEXICO AND PORTIONS OF WEST TEXAS...\\n\\n...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH\\nMONDAY EVENING FOR 20 FOOT WINDS OF 20 MPH OR GREATER, RELATIVE\\nHUMIDITY OF 15 PERCENT OR LESS, AND VERY HIGH FIRE DANGER ACROSS\\nSOUTHEAST NEW MEXICO AND PORTIONS OF WEST TEXAS...\\n\\n...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH\\nMONDAY EVENING FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY ACROSS SOUTHEAST\\nNEW MEXICO AND PORTIONS OF WEST TEXAS...\\n\\nThe National Weather Service in Midland/Odessa has issued a Red\\nFlag Warning for wind and low relative humidity, which is in\\neffect from noon CDT /11 AM MDT/ to 10 PM CDT /9 PM MDT/ Sunday.\\nA Fire Weather Watch has also been issued. This Fire Weather\\nWatch for wind and low relative humidity is in effect from Monday\\nafternoon through Monday evening. The Fire Weather Watch is no\\nlonger in effect.\\n\\n* WINDS...West 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph. Higher winds\\nand gusts in the mountains.\\n\\n* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 5 percent.\\n\\n* RFTI...6 to 8 or critical to extreme.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.\\nOutdoor burning is not recommended.\\n\\n* SEVERITY...\\n\\nFUELS (ERC)...70th-89th percentile...4 (out of 5).\\n\\nWEATHER...Near Critical...2 (out of 5).\\n\\nFIRE ENVIRONMENT...6 (out of 10). Instructions: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions\\nare either occurring now or will shortly. A combination of strong\\nwinds, low relative humidity and warm temperatures will increase\\npotential for fire growth.\\n\\nA Fire Weather Watch means that critical fire weather conditions\\nare forecast to occur. Listen for later forecasts and possible\\nRed Flag Warnings.\\n---\\n Event: Fire Weather Watch Area: Chinati Mountains Severity: Severe Description: ...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM NOON CDT /11 AM MDT/ TO 10 PM\\nCDT /9 PM MDT/ SUNDAY FOR 20 FOOT WINDS OF 20 MPH OR GREATER,\\nRELATIVE HUMIDITY OF 15 PERCENT OR LESS, AND VERY HIGH FIRE DANGER\\nACROSS SOUTHEAST NEW MEXICO AND PORTIONS OF WEST TEXAS...\\n\\n...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH\\nMONDAY EVENING FOR 20 FOOT WINDS OF 20 MPH OR GREATER, RELATIVE\\nHUMIDITY OF 15 PERCENT OR LESS, AND VERY HIGH FIRE DANGER ACROSS\\nSOUTHEAST NEW MEXICO AND PORTIONS OF WEST TEXAS...\\n\\n...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH\\nMONDAY EVENING FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR THE CHINATI\\nMOUNTAINS...\\n\\nThe National Weather Service in Midland/Odessa has issued a Red\\nFlag Warning for wind and low relative humidity, which is in\\neffect from noon to 10 PM CDT Sunday. A Fire Weather Watch has\\nalso been issued. This Fire Weather Watch for wind and low\\nrelative humidity is in effect from Monday afternoon through\\nMonday evening.\\n\\n* WINDS...West 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 35 mph.\\n\\n* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 6 percent.\\n\\n* RFTI...8 or extreme.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...\\n\\n* SEVERITY...\\n\\nFUELS (ERC)...70th-89th percentile...4 (out of 5).\\n\\nWEATHER...Near Critical...2 (out of 5).\\n\\nFIRE ENVIRONMENT...6 (out of 10). Instructions: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions\\nare either occurring now or will shortly. A combination of strong\\nwinds, low relative humidity and warm temperatures will increase\\npotential for fire growth.\\n\\nA Fire Weather Watch means that critical fire weather conditions\\nare forecast to occur. Listen for later forecasts and possible\\nRed Flag Warnings.\\n---\\n Event: Flood Warning Area: Anderson, TX; Cherokee, TX; Houston, TX; Trinity, TX Severity: Severe Description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Texas...\\n\\nNeches River Near Alto affecting Anderson, Cherokee, Houston and\\nTrinity Counties.\\n\\nFor the Neches River...including Lake Palestine, Neches, Alto,\\nDiboll, Rockland...Minor flooding is forecast.\\n\\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\\n\\n* WHERE...Neches River near Alto.\\n\\n* WHEN...Until Thursday afternoon.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Boat ramps and picnic areas near the river\\nwill begin to flood. Ranchers should move cattle and equipment\\nnear the river to higher ground.\\n\\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\\n- At 9:15 AM CDT Saturday the stage was 16.8 feet.\\n- Bankfull stage is 16.0 feet.\\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\\nending at 9:15 AM CDT Saturday was 17.1 feet.\\n- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage\\nearly Wednesday morning and continue falling to 15.3 feet\\nThursday morning.\\n- Flood stage is 16.0 feet.\\n- Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of\\n16.8 feet on 12/21/2018.\\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood Instructions: Do not drive cars through flooded areas.\\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\\nTurn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\\n\\nMotorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive\\ncars through flooded areas.\\n\\nFor more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website\\naddress into your favorite web browser URL bar:\\nhttps://water.noaa.gov/wfo/SHV\\n\\nThe next statement will be issued Sunday morning at 1045 AM CDT.\\n---\\n Event: Flood Warning Area: Angelina, TX; Nacogdoches, TX Severity: Severe Description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Texas...\\n\\nAngelina River Near Lufkin affecting Angelina and Nacogdoches\\nCounties.\\n\\nFor the Angelina River...including Alto, Lufkin...Minor flooding is\\nforecast.\\n\\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\\n\\n* WHERE...Angelina River near Lufkin.\\n\\n* WHEN...Until further notice.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...At 165.0 feet, Expect flooding to continue for several\\ndays with the majority of the gravel access roadway flooded.\\nBoaters and four wheel-operators should use caution traversing\\nboth upstream and downstream on the Angelina River as currents can\\nbecome swift and turbulent.\\n\\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\\n- At 10:00 AM CDT Saturday the stage was 163.9 feet.\\n- Bankfull stage is 158.5 feet.\\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\\nending at 10:00 AM CDT Saturday was 164.1 feet.\\n- Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 161.8 feet\\nThursday morning.\\n- Flood stage is 161.0 feet.\\n- Flood History...No available flood history.\\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood Instructions: Do not drive cars through flooded areas.\\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\\nTurn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\\n\\nMotorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive\\ncars through flooded areas.\\n\\nFor more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website\\naddress into your favorite web browser URL bar:\\nhttps://water.noaa.gov/wfo/SHV\\n\\nThe next statement will be issued Sunday morning at 1045 AM CDT.\\n---\\n Event: Flood Warning Area: Anderson, TX; Cherokee, TX; Houston, TX Severity: Severe Description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Texas...\\n\\nNeches River Near Neches affecting Anderson, Cherokee and Houston\\nCounties.\\n\\nFor the Neches River...including Lake Palestine, Neches, Alto,\\nDiboll, Rockland...Minor flooding is forecast.\\n\\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\\n\\n* WHERE...Neches River near Neches.\\n\\n* WHEN...Until Thursday morning.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding.  Move livestock\\nand equipment to higher ground away from the river.\\n\\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\\n- At 9:30 AM CDT Saturday the stage was 13.1 feet.\\n- Bankfull stage is 12.0 feet.\\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\\nending at 9:30 AM CDT Saturday was 13.4 feet.\\n- Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 13.4\\nfeet early Monday morning. It will then fall below flood\\nstage Wednesday afternoon.\\n- Flood stage is 12.0 feet.\\n- Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of\\n13.3 feet on 01/20/2017.\\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood Instructions: Do not drive cars through flooded areas.\\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\\nTurn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\\n\\nMotorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive\\ncars through flooded areas.\\n\\nFor more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website\\naddress into your favorite web browser URL bar:\\nhttps://water.noaa.gov/wfo/SHV\\n\\nThe next statement will be issued Sunday morning at 1045 AM CDT.\\n---\\n Event: Flood Warning Area: Gregg, TX; Smith, TX; Upshur, TX Severity: Severe Description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Texas...\\n\\nSabine River Near Gladewater affecting Gregg, Upshur and Smith\\nCounties.\\n\\nFor the Sabine River...including Mineola, Hawkins, Gladewater,\\nLongview, Beckville, Logansport...Minor flooding is forecast.\\n\\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\\n\\n* WHERE...Sabine River near Gladewater.\\n\\n* WHEN...Until Sunday afternoon.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...At 26.0 feet, Expect minor lowland flooding with camps\\nand picnic areas near the river suffering some flooding.\\n\\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\\n- At 9:15 AM CDT Saturday the stage was 26.6 feet.\\n- Bankfull stage is 25.0 feet.\\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\\nending at 9:15 AM CDT Saturday was 27.4 feet.\\n- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage\\nthis evening and continue falling to 15.2 feet Thursday\\nmorning.\\n- Flood stage is 26.0 feet.\\n- Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of\\n26.6 feet on 01/26/1954.\\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood Instructions: Do not drive cars through flooded areas.\\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\\nTurn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\\n\\nMotorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive\\ncars through flooded areas.\\n\\nFor more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website\\naddress into your favorite web browser URL bar:\\nhttps://water.noaa.gov/wfo/SHV\\n\\nThe next statement will be issued Sunday morning at 1045 AM CDT.\\n---\\n Event: Flood Warning Area: Angelina, TX; Houston, TX; Polk, TX; Trinity, TX; Tyler, TX Severity: Severe Description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Texas...\\n\\nNeches River Near Diboll affecting Tyler, Trinity, Angelina, Polk\\nand Houston Counties.\\n\\nFor the Neches River...including Lake Palestine, Neches, Alto,\\nDiboll, Rockland...Minor flooding is forecast.\\n\\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\\n\\n* WHERE...Neches River near Diboll.\\n\\n* WHEN...Until further notice.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding of boat ramps,\\npaths, and trails.  Move livestock and equipment to higher ground.\\n\\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\\n- At 9:15 AM CDT Saturday the stage was 13.4 feet.\\n- Bankfull stage is 12.0 feet.\\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\\nending at 9:15 AM CDT Saturday was 13.5 feet.\\n- Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 12.5 feet\\nThursday morning.\\n- Flood stage is 12.0 feet.\\n- Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of\\n13.4 feet on 05/10/1976.\\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood Instructions: Do not drive cars through flooded areas.\\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\\nTurn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\\n\\nMotorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive\\ncars through flooded areas.\\n\\nAdditional information is available at www.weather.gov/hgx.\\n\\nThe next statement will be issued late tonight at 330 AM CDT.\\n---\\n Event: Flood Warning Area: Polk, TX; San Jacinto, TX; Trinity, TX; Walker, TX Severity: Severe Description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Texas...\\n\\nTrinity River at Liberty affecting Liberty County.\\n\\nTrinity River near Moss Bluff affecting Liberty and Chambers\\nCounties.\\n\\n...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Texas...\\n\\nTrinity River at Riverside affecting Polk, San Jacinto, Trinity\\nand Walker Counties.\\n\\nFor the Trinity River...including Crockett, Riverside, Romayor,\\nGoodrich, Liberty, Moss Bluff...Moderate flooding is forecast.\\n\\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\\n\\n* WHERE...Trinity River at Riverside.\\n\\n* WHEN...Until further notice.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...At 135.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding continues as\\nsignificant backwater up Thomas Lake floods the lowest areas in\\nthe Green Rich Shore Subdivision in Walker County with the boat\\nramp completely inundated. The lowest lying areas in the Deep\\nRiver Plantation Subdivision and FM 980 northwest of Riverside are\\nthreatened.\\n\\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\\n- At 8:30 AM CDT Saturday the stage was 134.8 feet.\\n- Bankfull stage is 132.0 feet.\\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\\nending at 8:30 AM CDT Saturday was 135.0 feet.\\n- Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 133.5 feet\\nThursday morning.\\n- Flood stage is 133.5 feet.\\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood Instructions: Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\\n\\nMotorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive\\ncars through flooded areas.\\n\\nAdditional information is available at www.weather.gov/hgx.\\n\\nThe next statement will be issued late tonight at 330 AM CDT.\\n---\\n Event: Rip Current Statement Area: Matagorda Islands; Brazoria Islands; Galveston Island; Bolivar Peninsula Severity: Moderate Description: * WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.\\n\\n* WHERE...Gulf-facing beaches, including the Matagorda\\nPeninsula, Brazoria County beaches, Galveston Island and the\\nBolivar Peninsula.\\n\\n* WHEN...Through late Saturday night.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away\\nfrom shore into deeper water. Instructions: Swim near a lifeguard and away from rocks, jetties, and piers. If\\ncaught in a rip current, relax and float. Don't swim against the\\ncurrent. If able, swim in a direction following the shoreline. If\\nunable to escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.\\n---\\n Event: Red Flag Warning Area: Southwest Mountains; Southwest Deserts and Lowlands; El Paso; Hudspeth Severity: Severe Description: ...CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS TODAY THROUGH MONDAY FOR\\nSOUTHERN NEW MEXICO AND FAR WEST TEXAS...\\n\\n.Strong southwest flow aloft crossing the Southern Rockies will\\ninduce low surface pressure over the southern High Plains\\nSaturday through Monday. Subsequent tightening of the surface\\npressure gradient will increase winds area wide from the west-\\nsouthwest beginning this afternoon. Strongest winds are forecast\\nto occur Sunday and Monday afternoons, with peak gusts around 45\\nmph over the high terrain, gaps, and east slopes. Very dry air\\nremains in place while winds increase, creating critical fire\\ndanger for southern New Mexico and far west Texas. Fuel dryness\\nis near normal for mid-May, but weather conditions will be\\nfavorable for rapid drying of fine fuels and increasing ERCs back\\nabove seasonal normals through the weekend.\\n\\n...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH\\nMONDAY EVENING FOR STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY FOR SOUTHWEST NEW\\nMEXICO AND FAR WEST TEXAS...\\n\\n* AFFECTED AREA...In Texas, Fire Weather Zone 055 El Paso County,\\nFire Weather Zone 056 Hudspeth County/ In New Mexico, Fire\\nWeather Zone 110 Southwest Mountains/Gila NF/Apache NF/GLZ and\\nFire Weather Zone 111 Southwest Deserts and Lowlands/Las Cruces\\nBLM/GLZ.\\n\\n* TIMING...For Sunday, 11 AM to 9 PM. For Monday, 12 PM to 9 PM.\\n\\n* WINDS...Southwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.\\n\\n* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...5 to 10 percent.\\n\\n* EXPERIMENTAL RFTI...For Sunday, 5 to 7 or Critical to Extreme.\\nFor Monday, 5 to 7 or Critical to Extreme.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.\\nOutdoor burning is not recommended. Instructions: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions\\nare either occurring now, or will shortly. A combination of\\nstrong winds, low relative humidity, and warm temperatures can\\ncontribute to extreme fire behavior.\\n\\nA Fire Weather Watch means that critical fire weather conditions\\nare forecast to occur. Listen for later forecasts and possible\\nRed Flag Warnings.\\n---\\n Event: Fire Weather Watch Area: Southwest Mountains; Southwest Deserts and Lowlands; El Paso; Hudspeth Severity: Severe Description: ...CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS TODAY THROUGH MONDAY FOR\\nSOUTHERN NEW MEXICO AND FAR WEST TEXAS...\\n\\n.Strong southwest flow aloft crossing the Southern Rockies will\\ninduce low surface pressure over the southern High Plains\\nSaturday through Monday. Subsequent tightening of the surface\\npressure gradient will increase winds area wide from the west-\\nsouthwest beginning this afternoon. Strongest winds are forecast\\nto occur Sunday and Monday afternoons, with peak gusts around 45\\nmph over the high terrain, gaps, and east slopes. Very dry air\\nremains in place while winds increase, creating critical fire\\ndanger for southern New Mexico and far west Texas. For Monday, 12 PM to 9 PM.\\n\\n* WINDS...Southwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.\\n\\n* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...5 to 10 percent.\\n\\n* EXPERIMENTAL RFTI...For Sunday, 5 to 7 or Critical to Extreme.\\nFor Monday, 5 to 7 or Critical to Extreme.\\n\\n* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.\\nOutdoor burning is not recommended.
